ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: This was an excellent formal way to develop my research ideas further!
Great class, great professor, very helpful for anyone who wants to do or understand research.

The article readings were mainly focused on ecology-based topics, and without a background in ecology I found myself lacking an interest in these topics or struggling to understand them. The Honest Broker material was an extremely dull read. This book should not be required, but the topics could be discussed.
I enjoyed this course very much and found it to be extremely helpful.

This course is excellent for anyone wanting to conduct scientific research. The assignments for this course directly relate to each student's research interests, and provide a jump start for the semesters that follow.

My main comment would be to reduce the number/volume of reading required each week and choose a specificsubset of those readings to focus on. The readings were fine for the first part of the semester when courses in general were slow, however, when things became busier the consensus was that most students wouldn't even touch the reading since it seemed daunting.

Question 7a: Os was great, but I wish we had had more lectures with him. I feel like I got a lot out of the lecture classes, but fewer than half of the classes actually involved him lecturing.Question 7b: Hannah was a great TA; she facilitated conversation without forcing or leading it herself; I feel like I got a lot out of the discussion sections.
This course has no field trip so I decline to answer Question 9.

Q8: This was the best course I had this term. It was the only course that had a good amount of discussion, which I view as one of the most important aspects of graduate education, and which was sorely missing from my other classes. I appreciated that the assignments were meaningful, and resulted in not only useful skills and new insights, but in something that could be practically applied to advance one's goals as a scientist. Overall, I felt the expectations of students were within reason, and that most of the readings were valuable. The new perspective I gleaned from taking this course was inspiring, and I felt that the instructor did an excellent job of guiding students to a space where they could make connections within their own work, and come to greater clarity on their roles as scientists. I fear that I may fall into old habits in my thinking and approaches to research, and would consider taking (auditing) this class again in the future to help rejuvenate critical perspective.
The most useful course I took this semester - I got a polished proposal at the end of the semester.
I got credit for working on proposals that I would have written anyway and I got feedback on them.
The buildup to the final assignment is well-structured and well-timed for helping the student stay on top of it and to understand the progression of the work.
THe assistance of working through a real proposal for submission for funding, etc.
Basic philosophy of science and how to be a scentist.

The class was an exceptional learning tool for writing scientific grants and proposals. The tasks of writing proposals in steps forced a thought process which resulted in a complete understanding of the requirements. I also enjoyed the visit by the research office member. She was very helpful and explained our resources thoroughly.
I was able to learn how to focus my research with valuable proposal writing skills.
The top-notch instruction.
The course forced me to start seriously reading literature early in the semester and get me thinking carefully about what I want to do for the summer.

Learning the skills of writing successful research proposal. I like the way Professor divided the class lecture and discussion material for giving us a thorough technique of starting to ending the proposal writing.I think it would have been better if the course was geared towards all kinds of research but not just hard core scientific study.
Discussing science philosophy with people who have a diversity of scientific interests.
Working through the details of how to write a grant proposal, which I had never done before.
Learn the right altitude to do science research.

The best part of this course was learning to consider one's role as a scientist more critically than most of had before. While a portion of this course was preparing a research topic and working on grant development, I felt that the meat of it was really about thinking through how we interact with the world and our respective disciplines. In this way, I think this course would be invaluable for all FES students, not only those who are heading towards "hard" sciences or structured research. Other excellent parts of this course include numerous discussions, meaningful readings, and coursework that was front-loaded in the term.
I have a polished proposal to use for funding solicitations

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: I seemed pretty good as is, but it was a little annoying that only regular 2-year MESc students, not Yale College students or MESc5 students like me, were eligible for research funding.
Instructions were not always clear.

The instructor should be more explicit regarding what he expects in written work--either with an outright explanation of the grading rubric or, at the very least, a notice at the beginning of the course that not only what is mentioned in the assignment description.Some of the lectures felt too vague and or basic to be helpful.
It was extremely difficult, and felt skewed towards ecologist. It would be nice to have variance in the research of the professor and TAs.

The peer review board (mock grant panel) became a 'luck of the draw'. Depending on the audience reviewing the proposals, many were overlooked or not well understood, and therefore resulted in some strong proposals being thrown out. One review group felt forced to choose a "strong" proposal, while another group had many strong ones and had to throw out some that would dominate the other "forced chosen" ones. Maybe this process can be restructured; potentially by completing randomizing the papers reviewed by ALL students, rather than groups. Further, having the reviewed papers by anonymous. Unfortunately, there was some talk of advocating a paper because of friendships.
I enjoyed all parts and do not think that anything needs improvement.
None.

I wish the discussions had been more like a workshop for ideas on what research projects we had. I felt like what we did do wasn't particularly helpful to me, but maybe if there was more one on one interactions (exchanging papers with people and talking about them in depth, instead of talking shallowly as a group about everyone's) might have been a lot more helpful. It's hard because we have a lot of different interests in the class, but maybe grouping people doing similar work (modelers with modelers, ecosystem services with ecosystem services, ect) would have been good.
Addition of topics in course lecture and reading things related to science and policy. The recent trend of research such as something on modeling.
The reading volume as noted earlier.
More lectures with Os.
How to write a scientific proposal.

This course does not need significant improvement. One possible addition that could be nice would be to bring in students further along in their research to talk about their individual processes, thereby offering insight and perspective on the road to come.

Perhaps a more structured approach for the annotated bibliography would be useful - instead of 15 papers due at once - perhaps 5 due on general background, then 5 due on papers related directly to your topic, then 5 due on papers that were conducted at your field site.

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Os was great!
The TA was very helpful and available.
Both the professor and the TA were always available for help. Very responsive to emails and free for meetings. The TA read over multiple drafts of my work and always offered helpful feedback.

TAs were very helpful, quickly responded to all questions, and generally laid out what was expected. I think for the future, what is required of the assignments should be laid out more clearly for what the professor grades, because certainly I would have done better if I knew what the professor was looking for. Maybe this is just because some people have less experience with research and natural resource research than others, but the people with less experience could do just as well as the people without experience if they were told what sorts of things were expected.
Ta is really helpful in giving students suggestions for presentation and proposal.
Both the TA and instructor were available for help when needed. They offered sound advice and were very knowledgeable on the subjects.
Both the instructor and TA were always available for help and questions.
Help was available and readily provided, and was of high quality.
Hannah Bement was excellent.
Kevin is amazing.
TA has been very helpful with my proposal writing. She has given her time to go through my proposal twice. I think she did a very good job on editing my proposal.
Both the professor and TA were amazing at responding to questions and comments in class, via email, and in person outside of class.
Didn't really ask Os for help, but Hannah was helpful and responsive when I had questions.

The instructor and TAs were available for assistance by appointment. I found them both helpful in working through topical challenges and reviewing my materials. I was particularly impressed with the amount of time that was offered by the TA in my discussion section, for reviewing student work.
I received good feedback, and the TA was very helpful and pleasant to work with.

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: Even though I'm a MESc5 and finishing up my master's research, this was a very helpful class. I used it to develop my ideas for what I want to begin working on in my doctoral work (not at Yale) next year. Having a formal class to do this and get feedback was fantastic.

Very important to have for research, and if you want to do research you need to take this class, both as curriculum but also because it's a really good stepping stone. I don't have much research methods background.

The class was extremely helpful overall and a great learning experience. The course is vital for my overall program, because I hope to continue research over time. I have taken a research methods course during my undergraduate degree and did not receive the same quality and quantity of skills as I received from this course.
It helped to guide my research for my program.
This course focused and accelerated my research plans for the coming semesters.

It was good that I started reading literature as early as this class made me, because it made me realize that I don't want to do the project I had in mind during the first halfof the semester. Now I have time to figure out a project that it more feasible and potentially useful before the funding deadlines in February.

It will always give me the skill of writing proposal for any kind of work I do in my life. I had lacked this skill in my previous works so I plan to use the proposal writing skill in writing papers for other courses to make an impact on decision making by science, such as through science advocate approach.

Clearly this course was necessary for my degree, however, it was probably most useful towards my career as it provided the forum by which likeminded, and sometimes dissimilar, thinking students to discuss important scientific concepts.
Extremely important- required for MESc but also a useful class as grant/ proposal-writing is a key skill for most environmental careers.
This course provides me an introductory to science study, which is very useful.

At the moment, I plan to conduct research during my time at FES and in future education. This course was an essential piece of that process in terms of developing requisite skills in grant acquisition. In addition, I have always felt that strong research skills are essential for all scientists, and knew that regardless of my current researchneeds, there would be value in thinking critically about the ways that I approach and think about science as a research-based discipline.

Extremely helpful to my project development. I'm surprised that all the FES students aren't required to take some variation of this course. It was extremely useful in helping me to develop my interests and direct my focus for the remainder of my time at Yale.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: It's required of all MESc students and I thought it would be useful.
To become better at writing grant applications.
it's required for MeSC.

Although this is a required course for my program, I feel I would have attended it regardless. I wanted to become comfortable writing research grants and proposals and gain the skills needed to successfully locate resources and execute research/funding proposals.
I wanted to learn how to improve my research skills and project design abilities.
It is mandatory.
requirement; recommended by second years.

I thought since I will be collecting ecological data it would be more useful than social science methods (though I wish there was some way to combine the two, since I think social science is so important for good conservation science). I liked that the emphasis was on creating a proposal.

I was planning to work on a project during my summer break. For which I needed to develop a proposal to apply for funding and grant. I think I did a pretty good job of developing a proposal though there are ample work I need to put in to improve it to the level of getting good grant.
Mandatory
Required for MESc, but also wanted guidance with project proposal creation.
It is a mandatory course.
As above...
To develop a proposal

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes, definitely. It was better than expected.
Yes.
Yes
Yes, I learnt a lot.

Yes - the course lived up to my expectations and more. I was surprised to see how my writing skills developed over the semester. I am more confident in writing grants and proposals, which was one of my goals prior to this course.
Yes, it aided in teaching me how to write a proposal and to narrow my research goals.
Yes, above and beyond.
Yes.
I expected a lot more workshoping of ideas among classmates. I've had some very productive conversations about methods with people in the class, but they all took place outside of the class itself.
Yes, kind of
It exceeded them.
Yes.
Yes, it did.
Yes. This course was the best that I took this term, and met my expectations for quality, rigor, and engagement.
Yes

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes, definitely.
I found the coursework extremely helpful but the readings and the lectures less so.
No, but nothing is how you expect it.
Yes - see above.
Yes, it was an excellent course.
Yes.
Yes.
Sure

I kind of regret saying that I didn't live up to my expectation because it was my fault that I could not give the time it required. I wish I had more time to put into it and learn more.But I am happy with what I learned from the class.
I got more than I expected.
Yes.

I did. I developed skills in proposal writing, refined my current research interests, produced two proposals, and applied for funding. That was more than I expected, so I finished feeling more than satisfied.
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: N/A
Na
More time for student discussions

A number of students from the course met outside of class to help review our grant proposals due for the course and for outside opportunities. This allowed us to get opinions on our efforts throughout the course, share knowledge, and make suggestions for improvements. Through this flow of information, we all saw dramatic improvements to our writing tasks.
More group discussion!

We had discussion classes every week on different techniques of analyzing papers, criticizing. I think best part of the course were these group discussion because I had a new experience. I observed how my fellow students tackled with different skills and learned a lot from them.These group discussion classes has been the most productive part of the course. Though I participating less, but I learned a lot from others' discussions.
yes, but it was an optional group setting for revising grant proposals
Advantage: Brainstorm.Disadvantage: More group work in class will be better.

My work groups was not formal, but on a couple of occasions I met with peers to review one another's proposals. This was helpful in gaining new insight, learning to write more critically, and in gaining exposure to as many proposals as possible. I would recommend at least one self-motivated peer review process for all students in this course.
Did not participate

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Get started on your research proposal early on so that your ideas have time to marinate over the course of the semester. Seek feedback on your proposal and ideas from your fellow students, labmates, and advisor(s).
Be meticulous and work above and beyond what you think is necessary. You will get much more out of it and you will do much better.

Read some ecology papers and some papers of the professors, so that the course will be easier to follow. Have a specific research plan in mind at the beginning of the course, and advisers and literature picked out to support your research.
Very good training and information for those who want to do scientific research.

Do not wait until the last minute to work on the course's assignments. Always seek advice from the instructor, TAs,and fellow students. If the assignment says "use at least 10 sources", always use more. Not only is this expected (but unsaid) but it will help you develop a more sound argument/basis. Edit, edit, and then edit again. Follow the advice of the instructor and others - always have non-scientists review your work, and have as many people as possible review your work.
I would tell students to learn as much as possible from the instructor, TA, and readings. They are all invaluable resources!
Try to refine your research interests as early as possible, and read journal articles in your field ahead of time, if possible.

If you are torn between the two Methods classes, think hard about what you need to have a firmer grounding in. The ethics in this class, and the discussion of science journals and how to "play the game" were great and helpful if you want to be a scientist or academic, but if you are more interested in on the ground management, especially in developing countries, I would say consider the Social Science class. I think this class is definitely helpful for people on the science track, but for someone who is not heading to academic science I sometimes felt like the discussions weren't relevant to me.
If you are planning to do a research project as your master project, take this class. It is very helpful.
Keep up on writing your grant. This is vital and will only prove beneficial both in the short run and also in the long run.
Take the time to do a good job on the annotated bibliography. It has to be done, so the more time you spend doing it right, the more time you save down the road.
Do not hesitate to ask questions in class.

1.) The course is front-loaded in terms of workload, so don't procrastinate. You will be happy you kept up when you finish your assignments weeks before the rest of your term papers and exams.2.) This course is valuable for all scientists, even if you don't want to apply for funding.3.) The readings are, for the most part, worth your while, so do them!
Get the details of your project figured out early in the semester.
